Policy title: Short title; Congressional declaration of purpose and policy
Policy description: To promote the full flow of commerce, prescribe legitimate rights of employees and employers, and provide procedures for preventing interference with these rights.
Defines industry affecting commerce, strike, and various other terms used in this chapter.
Protects the rights of employees to quit their jobs and ensures no individual can be forced to work without consent.
If any provision of this chapter is held invalid, the remainder remains unaffected.
Establishes the importance of protecting employee rights to collective bargaining to prevent labor disputes that affect commerce.
Provides legal definitions for terms such as employer, employee, labor organization, supervisor, etc.
Continues the Board as an agency of the U.S. with five members appointed by the President and establishes a general counsel to supervise legal functions.

Policy title: Right of employees as to organization, collective bargaining, etc.
Policy description: Employees have the right to form unions, bargain collectively, and engage in concerted activities.
Defines prohibited practices for employers (interference with employee rights, discrimination based on union membership) and unions (coercion, refusal to bargain).
Governs the process for selecting collective bargaining representatives.
Empowers the NLRB to investigate and prevent unfair labor practices and seek enforcement through courts.
Ensures that, except where limited, employees retain the right to strike.
Establishes policies to minimize labor disputes affecting commerce through conference and collective bargaining.
Category: Labor-Management Relations - Conciliation of Labor Disputes

Policy description: Creates an independent agency under a Director appointed by the President to provide mediation and conciliation services.
Category: Labor-Management Relations - Conciliation of Labor Disputes

Policy description: Outlines the role of the Service in settling disputes, preventing interruptions in commerce, and encouraging voluntary dispute resolution.
Category: Labor-Management Relations - Conciliation of Labor Disputes

Policy title: Co-equal obligations of employees, their representatives, and management
Policy description: Requires employers and employees to exert reasonable efforts to maintain agreements and settle disputes through conferences.
Category: Labor-Management Relations - Conciliation of Labor Disputes

Policy description: Establishes a 12-member panel appointed by the President to advise on avoiding industrial controversies.
Category: Labor-Management Relations - Conciliation of Labor Disputes

Policy title: National emergencies; appointment of board of inquiry
Policy description: Allows the President to appoint a board of inquiry when a strike threatens national health or safety.
Outlines the composition, compensation, and powers of the board of inquiry.
Authorizes the President to direct the Attorney General to seek an injunction against strikes imperiling national health or safety.
Requires parties to attempt settlement with the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service after an injunction is issued.

Policy title: Discharge of injunction upon certification of results
Policy description: Requires the Attorney General to move to discharge an injunction once a settlement or employee vote is completed.
Requires the Bureau of Labor Statistics to maintain a file of collective bargaining agreements for public inspection.
Category: Labor-Management Relations - Conciliation of Labor Disputes

Policy description: Excludes matters subject to the Railway Labor Act from the provisions of this subchapter.
Category: Labor-Management Relations - Conciliation of Labor Disputes

Policy title: Conciliation of labor disputes in the health care industry
Policy description: Authorizes the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to establish boards of inquiry for health care industry labor disputes.
Category: Labor-Management Relations - Conciliation of Labor Disputes

Policy title: Suits by and against labor organizations
Policy description: Enables labor organizations to sue or be sued in federal district courts without respect to the amount in controversy.
Prohibits employers from making certain payments to labor organizations, with specified exceptions.
Prohibits unfair labor practices as defined under section 158(b)(4).
This section, which prohibited government employees from striking, was repealed on Aug. 9, 1955.
Related to the establishment and composition of the Joint Committee on Labor-Management Relations.
Related to a study by the committee of the entire field of labor-management relations.
Required a final report to Congress to be submitted no later than March 1, 1949.
Encourages worker organizing and collective bargaining and establishes a task force chaired by the Vice President to identify executive policies promoting worker rights.
This chapter may be cited as the 'Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938'.

Policy title: Congressional Finding and Declaration of Policy
Policy description: Declares that detrimental labor conditions in industries engaged in commerce burden commerce, perpetuate unfair competition, lead to labor disputes, and affect the fair marketing of goods.
Defines terms such as 'employee', 'employer', 'commerce', 'wage', and 'oppressive child labor' within the scope of the Act.
Establishes the Wage and Hour Division in the Department of Labor under an Administrator appointed by the President, and outlines reporting and enforcement responsibilities.
Sets federal minimum wage standards and provides for periodic adjustments. Current rate is $7.25 per hour with special provisions for certain categories of workers.
Limits the number of working hours per week to 40 hours before overtime pay (1.5x regular rate) applies, with exceptions for certain collective bargaining agreements.
Authorizes enforcement agencies to require witness testimony for investigations.
Provides for judicial review of wage determinations in U.S. territories such as Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.
Mandates data collection on labor conditions and authorizes investigations of wages, hours, and employment conditions.
Prohibits oppressive child labor and sets regulations for employment of minors, including restrictions on shipment of goods made with child labor.
Specifies industries and employees exempt from wage and hour requirements, including executives, agricultural workers, and computer professionals.
Allows employment of disabled individuals, students, and apprentices at special wage rates under certain conditions.
Lists violations of the Fair Labor Standards Act including shipping goods produced in violation of standards, violating wage and hour regulations, and retaliating against employees.
Establishes penalties for violations, including fines up to $10,000, imprisonment up to 6 months for repeat offenders, and civil liabilities for unpaid wages and damages.
Allows district courts to restrain violations of labor laws, including withholding of wages.
Clarifies that more protective state/local laws take precedence over federal standards and ensures protections for certain federal employees.
Mandates employers to provide notices regarding employee rights related to health insurance exchanges and coverage information.
Provides protections against employer retaliation for employees asserting rights or reporting violations under this law.
Requires employers to provide reasonable break time and private space for nursing mothers to express milk for one year after childbirth.
Ensures that if any provision of the Act is found invalid, the remainder stays in effect.
